abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is highly likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. These are some of the lessons learned from
            this project: Strong and continued Borrower commitment to
            the project objectives during implementation was critical to
            a successful project outcome. Payment for part of the
            technical assistance provided to the participating banks
            contributed to a reinforced ownership of the project
            objectives. Although the project was designed carefully and
            potential risks were identified correctly-for example, there
            was weak Borrower commitment to bank privatization and a
            resulting lack of interest by the foreign strategic
            investors)-- both the Bank and the Government gave
            insufficient attention to addressing the emerging
            discrepancies and constraints during project implementation.
            Implementation of the Loan raised questions about the
            ultimate effectiveness of the technical assistance provided
            and the probability of successful bank privatization while
            state owned enterprises continue to dominate the economy.
            The technical assistance delivered could have been even more
            effective if the consultants had been more familiar with
            local practices and circumstances and had they been more
            actively involved in implementing their recommendations. In
            a technical assistance project such as this, these two
            requirements would need to be part of the consultants'
            terms of reference. A well-functioning project
            implementation unit staffed with competent and committed
            people, fairly remunerated and trained, is essential for a
            successful implementation of a multi-component and complex
            project such as this. The Bank and the counterparts used a
            flexible approach to design and implement best practice
            solutions. Combining components 1, 2 and 3 under one
            component resulted in significantly lower contract values
            and costs. Although the FIBL task management changed over
            the course of the life of the project, key staff supervised
            the project during the whole implementation period. This
            continuity contributed to the success of the project.
            Although privatization of the banks was not an objective,
            the latter provided a platform to conduct a dialogue on bank
            privatization. However, a technical assistance project
            cannot serve as a vehicle for addressing difficult policy
            issues such as privatization of state banks or enterprises.
            A policy based adjustment operation would be required to
            support such fundamental systemic reforms.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Institution Building
            Project for Uzbekistan aims to a) improve corporate
            governance and management capacity of the commercial banks
            in preparation for privatization; b) increase competition
            between commercial banks and boost the efficiency and
            innovation of the banking system; and c) improve prudential
            regulations and strengthen the supervision capacity of the
            central bank. There are six components. The first provides
            technical assistance to selected banks addressing treasury
            and financial risk management, strategic planning,
            accounting, internal audits, management information systems
            (MIS), and credit risk management. Experts will be placed in
            participating banks in order to design and implement
            reforms. The second component provides technical assistance
            to all commercial banks, and funds training in critical risk
            management areas. The third component strengthens the
            legal/regulatory and supervisory capacity of the central
            bank. The fourth component strengthens the MIS available to
            support bank manager decisionmaking; upgrades payments
            systems, improves telecommunications performance supporting
            MIS and payments systems; and establishes a global security
            system to safeguard the commercial banks' data transfer
            networks. The fifth component funds bank privatization and
            restructuring. The sixth component supports the
            strengthening of the project implementation unit.
